revision.text:
{{other people}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Alan Young | image = Alan Young circa 1944.JPG | caption = Young in 1944 | birth_name = Angus Young | birth_date = {{birth date|1919|11|19}} | birth_place = [[North Shields]], [[Northumberland]], [[England]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|05|19|1919|11|19}} | death_place = [[Woodland Hills, Los Angeles]], [[United States]] | citizenship = {{ubl|[[British nationality law|British]] (1919–1925)|[[Canadian nationality law|Canadian]] (1925–2016)|[[United States nationality law|American]] (1944–2016)}} | occupation = {{Flatlist| *Actor *voice actor *comedian *radio host *television host }} | years_active = 1939–2016 | known_for = {{ubl|Wilbur Post in ''[[Mister Ed]]''|Voice of [[Scrooge McDuck]]}} | spouse = {{unbulleted list|{{marriage|Mary Anne Grimes
|1941|1947|reason=divorced}}|{{marriage|Virginia McCurdy
|1948|1995|reason=divorced}}|{{marriage|Mary Chipman
|1996|1997|reason=divorced}}}} | children = 4 | awards = [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series|Primetime Emmy Award for Best Actor]] }} [[File:Mister Ed main cast 2.JPG|thumb|[[Connie Hines]] and Alan Young in TV's ''[[Mister Ed]]'' ]] '''Alan Young''' (born '''Angus Young'''; November 19, 1919 – May 19, 2016) was a [[British Americans|British–American]] actor, voice actor, comedian and radio and television host/personality who ''[[TV Guide]]'' called "The [[Charlie Chaplin]] of Television". He was best known for his role as naive Wilbur Post in the television comedy series ''[[Mister Ed]]'' (1961–1966). Young was also the voice of Disney's [[Scrooge McDuck]] for over thirty years, first in the [[Academy Award]]-nominated short film ''[[Mickey's Christmas Carol]]'' (1983) and in various other films, TV series and video games until his death. During the 1940s and 1950s, he starred in his own variety/comedy sketch shows ''[[The Alan Young Show]]'' on radio and television, the latter gaining him two [[Primetime Emmy Award|Emmy Awards]] in 1951. He also appeared in a number of feature films, starting from 1946, including the 1960 film ''[[The Time Machine (1960 film)|The Time Machine]]'' and from the 1980s gaining a new generation of viewers appearing in numerous [[Walt Disney Productions]] films as both an actor and voice actor. [[File:Alan Young.jpg|thumb|right|Alan Young with [[Olga San Juan]]]] ==Early life== Young was born as Angus Young on November 19, 1919, in [[North Shields]], [[Northumberland]], England, to [[Scottish people|Scottish]] parents. (In his later years he claimed he had been born in 1924.) His father was a mine worker and a tap dancer, and his mother was a singer. The family moved to [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]], when Young was a toddler and to [[West Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]], when he was six years old. Young came to love radio when bedridden as a child because of severe [[asthma]].{{cite news |last1=Barnes |first1=Mike |last2=Byrnes |first2=Duane |date=May 20, 2016 |title=Alan Young, Two-Legged Star of 'Mister Ed,' Dies at 96 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/alan-young-dead-mister-ed-816846 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |location= |access-date=May 20, 2016 }}{{cite news |last=Shapiro |first=T. Rees |date=May 20, 2016 |title=Alan Young, Actor Who Played Willllburrrrr on ‘Mister Ed,’ Dies at 96 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/alan-young-actor-who-played-wilbur-on-mister-ed-dies-at-96/2016/05/20/88ae8838-1ed4-11e6-8c7b-6931e66333e7_story.html |work=The Washington Post |location= |access-date=May 20, 2016 }} By the time he was in high school, Young had his own comedy radio series on the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] network, but he left it during the [[Second World War]] to serve in the [[Royal Canadian Navy]].{{cite news |last=Elbur |first=Lynn |date=May 20, 2016 |title=Alan Young, Star of 1960s sitcom 'Mr. Ed,' Dies at 96|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/7dc308dd967d4703aeffd12143b647b4/alan-young-star-1960s-sitcom-mr-ed-dies-96 |work=Associated Press |location= |access-date=May 20, 2016 }}{{cite book |last= Stevens |first= Christopher |title= Born Brilliant: The Life Of Kenneth Williams |publisher= John Murray |year= 2010 |isbn = 1-84854-195-3 |page=368}} He later resigned his Navy commission after learning he would be spending his time writing for a Navy show, and he attempted to join the [[Canadian Army]]. According to some sources, the Army rejected him due to his childhood asthma.{{cite news |last=Dunham |first=Will |date=May 20, 2016 |title=Actor Alan Young, Human Star of Horse Sitcom 'Mister Ed,' Dies at 96 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-people-alanyoung-idUSKCN0YB2SJ |work=Reuters |location= |access-date=May 20, 2016 }} ==Career== After leaving the service, Young moved to [[Toronto]] and resumed his Canadian radio career, where he was discovered by an American agent who brought him to [[New York City|New York]] in 1944 to appear on American radio. Young's first American radio appearances were on the ''Philco Radio Hall of Fame''. This led to his own show, ''[[The Alan Young Show]]'', [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]]'s summer replacement for the series ''[[Eddie Cantor|The Eddie Cantor Show]]''. He switched to [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] two years later, then returned to NBC.[https://books.google.com/books?id=EwtRbXNca0oC&pg=PA20 On the Air: The Encyclopedia of Old-Time Radio] John Dunning; Oxford University Press, pp20–21 Young's film debut was in ''[[Margie (film)|Margie]]'' (1946), and he was featured in ''[[Chicken Every Sunday]]'' (1949).{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=Bob|title=Comic Alan Young Critical of TV|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WW1QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VhAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5217,4930447&dq=alan-young&hl=en|newspaper=The Milwaukee Sentinel|date=June 10, 1959}} In 1950, the television version of ''The Alan Young Show'' began. By 1951, the series received not only praise, but also several [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s, including Best Actor and Most Outstanding Personality for Young.{{cite web|title=Nominations Search|url=http://www.emmys.com/awards/nominations/award-search?search_api_views_fulltext=%22alan+young%22&submit=Search&field_celebrity_details_field_display_name=&field_show_details_field_nominee_show_nr_title=&field_show_details_field_network=All&field_show_details_field_production_company=All&field_nominations_year=1949-01-01+00%3A00%3A00&field_nominations_year_1=2016-01-01+00%3A00%3A00&field_award_category=All|publisher=[[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]]|accessdate=25 May 2016}} After its cancellation, Young continued to act in films, among which ''[[Androcles and the Lion (film)|Androcles and the Lion]]'' (1952) and ''[[Gentlemen Marry Brunettes]]'' (1955), and two [[George Pal]] films, ''[[Tom Thumb (film)|Tom Thumb]]'' (1958) and ''[[The Time Machine (1960 film)|The Time Machine]]'' (1960). He appeared in the NBC espionage drama ''[[Five Fingers (TV series)|Five Fingers]]'' ("Thin Ice", 1959), starring [[David Hedison]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=37SSBAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover There's No Business Like Show Business...Was] Alan Young; BearManor Media, Jul 5, 2006, multiple mentions Young was best known, however, for ''[[Mister Ed]]'' (1961–66), a [[Columbia Broadcasting System|CBS]] television show, in which he starred as Wilbur Post, the owner of Mr. Ed, a talking horse who would not talk to anyone but him, thus causing comic situations for Wilbur Post, with his wife, neighbors, and acquaintances.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19610318&id=HD4mAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4v4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=2227,2840363|work=The Gettysburg Times|date=March 18, 1961|title=Alan Young In ''Mister Ed''|accessdate=}} He also starred as Stanley Beamish in the unaired 1966 pilot episode of ''[[Mr. Terrific (TV series)|Mr. Terrific]]'', but apparently declined to appear in the broadcast series in 1967 that followed. In the late 1960s, he retired from acting for several years. During that time, he founded a broadcast division for the [[Christian Science]] Church.[https://books.google.com/books?id=4tcxAQAAIAAJ&q=%22alan+young%22+%22christian+science%22+broadcast&dq=%22alan+young%22+%22christian+science%22+broadcast&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj7pZq5yvXMAhVGLlIKHSYICkwQ6AEIIjAB TV Guide 1974] page 36 "Well, he's come back to Hollywood after spending the past six years as a Christian Science lecturer in Boston and other parts of the country. "I set up a film and broadcasting department for the mother church in Boston," Young said" During the 1970s, Young became active in voice acting. After 1974, he voiced [[Scrooge McDuck]] in numerous [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] films and in the popular series ''[[DuckTales]]'' (1987-1990). In ''[[Mickey's Christmas Carol]]'', he portrayed the character's miserly [[Ebenezer Scrooge|namesake]]. He also played Scrooge in video games such as the ''[[Kingdom Hearts]]'' series, ''[[DuckTales: Remastered]]'' in 2013, and the ''[[Mickey Mouse (TV series)|Mickey Mouse]]'' cartoon "Goofy's First Love" released in 2015. Apart from Scrooge McDuck, his other prominent roles were [[Farmer Smurf]] on ''[[The Smurfs (TV series)|The Smurfs]]'', Haggis McHaggis on ''[[The Ren & Stimpy Show]]'', 7-Zark-7, Keyop in ''[[Battle of the Planets]]'', and Hiram Flaversham in ''[[The Great Mouse Detective]]''. He also guest starred on ''[[The Love Boat]]'', ''[[The Incredible Hulk (1982 TV series)|The Incredible Hulk]]'', ''[[The New Scooby and Scrappy-Doo Show]]'', and ''[[Spider-Man and His Amazing Friends]]''.{{cite web|url=http://voicechasers.com/database/showprod.php?prodid=160|title=Spider-Man and His Amazing Friends (1981, Animated Series) Voice Cast|website=Voice Chasers}} Young later starred in the sitcom ''[[Coming of Age (1988 TV series)|Coming of Age]]'' for two seasons from 1988-89. In 1991, Alan Young returned to the stage, starring as Cap'n Andy Hawkes in the [[California Musical Theatre]]'s adaptation of ''[[Show Boat]]''. He had been called for the role after [[Van Johnson]], who was initially cast in the part, was hospitalised.{{cite news|author=Sylvie Drake|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-09-16/entertainment/ca-1756_1_show-boat-stage|date=September 16, 1991|title=Stage: 'Show Boat' Afloat Without Its Star|accessdate=}} He had also appeared in the plays ''[[A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum]]'' and ''The Girl With the Freudian Slip''. In 1993, he recreated his role as Filby for the mini-sequel to [[George Pal]]'s ''The Time Machine'', reuniting him with [[Rod Taylor]], who had played George, the Time Traveller. It was called ''[[Time Machine: The Journey Back]]'', directed by Clyde Lucas. In 1994, Young co-starred in the [[Eddie Murphy]] film ''[[Beverly Hills Cop III]]''. He played the role of Uncle Dave Thornton, the [[Walt Disney]]-esque founder of the fictional California theme park Wonderworld, and in that same year, Young played the role of Charlie in the television film, ''Hart to Hart: Home Is Where the Hart Is''.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} After 1994, he played at least eight characters, including antique dealer Jack Allen on the radio drama ''[[Adventures in Odyssey]]''. In 1997, he did the voice of [[Haggis McMutton]] in the PC game ''[[The Curse of Monkey Island]]''. His later guest roles in animated series included ''[[Megas XLR]]'', ''[[Static Shock]]'', ''[[House of Mouse]]'', ''[[The Ren & Stimpy Show]]'', ''[[Duckman]]'', ''[[Batman: The Animated Series]]'' and ''[[TaleSpin]]''.[http://www.behindthevoiceactors.com/Alan-Young/ Alan Young's voiceography]. Behind the Voice Actors.com – check mark indicates BTVA has verified the entries using screenshots of credits and other confirmed sources. In 2002, he had a cameo as the flower store worker in [[Simon Wells]]' remake of ''[[The Time Machine (2002 film)|The Time Machine]]'', and in 2010, he read [[H.G. Wells]]'s [[The Time Machine|original novel]] for 7th Voyage Productions, Inc. Young's television guest roles include ''[[Gibbsville (TV series)|Gibbsville]]'', ''[[The Love Boat]]'', ''[[Murder, She Wrote]]'', ''[[St. Elsewhere]]'', ''[[Coach (TV series)|Coach]]'', ''[[Party of Five]]'', ''[[The Wayans Bros.]]'', ''[[USA High]]'', ''[[Hang Time (TV series)|Hang Time]]'', ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', ''[[Maybe It's Me (TV series)|Maybe It's Me]]'', and ''[[Sabrina, the Teenage Witch (1996 TV series)|Sabrina, the Teenage Witch]]'' ("Sweet Charity", 1997) in which he played Zelda's love interest.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} ==Personal life and death== Young was married three times.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/alan-young-actor-who-played-wilbur-on-mister-ed-dies-at-96/2016/05/20/88ae8838-1ed4-11e6-8c7b-6931e66333e7_story.html|title=Alan Young, actor who played Willllburrrrr on ‘Mister Ed,’ dies at 96|author= T. Rees Shapiro |date=May 20, 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=May 20, 2016}} He and Mary Anne Grimes were married from 1941 to 1947 and had two children. He married Virginia McCurdy in 1948, and they had two children. They divorced in 1995, with Young marrying Mary Chipman the following year, but Young and Chipman then divorced in 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.amny.com/entertainment/celebrities/alan-young-dead-mister-ed-star-was-96-1.11823902|title=Alan Young dead; 'Mister Ed' star was 96|author=Reuters|publisher=[[AM New York]]|date=May 20, 2016|accessdate=May 20, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160522122307/http://www.amny.com/entertainment/celebrities/alan-young-dead-mister-ed-star-was-96-1.11823902|archivedate=May 22, 2016|df=mdy-all}} He was a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]].{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QfHXAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA173&dq=Martha+Tilton+Republican&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwir-8ivuLDTAhUM8IMKHU_XAPUQ6AEILjAC#v=onepage&q=Alan+Young&f=false|title=When Hollywood Was Right: How Movie Stars, Studio Moguls, and Big Business Remade American Politics|first=Donald T.|last=Critchlow|date=October 21, 2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|via=Google Books}} Young later lived in [[Woodland Hills, California]], at the [[Motion Picture & Television Country House and Hospital]], a retirement community, where he died of natural causes on May 19, 2016, at the age of 96. == Filmography == === Radio === {|class="wikitable" ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Role |- | 1997 | ''[[The Curse of Monkey Island]]'' | [[Haggis McMutton]] |- | 2008 | ''[[Disney Think Fast]]'' | rowspan="4" | Scrooge McDuck |- | 2009 | ''[[Kingdom Hearts Birth by Sleep]]'' |- | 2013 | ''[[Disney Magical World]]'' |- | 2013 | ''[[DuckTales: Remastered]]'' |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Alan Young}} * {{official website|https://web.archive.org/web/20050203185303/http://www.mister-ed.tv/}} * {{IMDb name|0949241}} * {{emmytvlegends name|alan-young}} *[http://www.outlawsgameroom.com/misc.php?page=152 The Alan Young Show at Outlaws Old Time Radio Corner] {{EmmyAward ComedyLeadActor 1950-1975}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Young, Alan}} [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:People from North Shields]] [[Category:English male film actors]] [[Category:English emigrants to Canada]] [[Category:English male radio actors]] [[Category:English male television actors]] [[Category:English male voice actors]] [[Category:English male stage actors]] [[Category:English male comedians]] [[Category:English male video game actors]] [[Category:Outstanding Performance by a Lead Actor in a Comedy Series Primetime Emmy Award winners]] [[Category:English Christian Scientists]] [[Category:English people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:English emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:American male voice actors]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male radio actors]] [[Category:American male comedians]] [[Category:American male video game actors]] [[Category:Canadian male voice actors]] [[Category:Canadian male film actors]] [[Category:Canadian male radio actors]] [[Category:Canadian male comedians]] [[Category:Canadian male video game actors]] [[Category:Walt Disney Animation Studios people]] [[Category:Hanna-Barbera people]] [[Category:California Republicans]] [[Category:Comedians from California]]
